articles.headline: After Clash, Manchin and Schumer Rushed to Reset Climate and Tax Deal
articles.snippet: The West Virginia Democrat said he had relented and agreed to sign on to a climate, energy and tax package after returning to negotiations to draft a version that would combat inflation.
articles.abstract: The West Virginia Democrat said he had relented and agreed to sign on to a climate, energy and tax package after returning to negotiations to draft a version that would combat inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, and Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, were both nursing resentments when they met secretly in a windowless room in the basement of the Capitol last Monday to try to salvage a climate package that was a key piece of their party’s agenda.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Annie Karni

articles.headline: 2016 Campaign Looms Large as Justice Dept. Pursues Jan. 6 Inquiry
articles.snippet: Top officials at the department and the F.B.I. appear intent on avoiding any errors that could taint the current investigation or provide ammunition for a backlash.
articles.abstract: Top officials at the department and the F.B.I. appear intent on avoiding any errors that could taint the current investigation or provide ammunition for a backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Justice Department investigation into the attack on the Capitol grinds ever closer to former President Donald J. Trump, it has prompted persistent — and cautionary — reminders of the backlash caused by inquiries into Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton during the 2016 presidential campaign.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Adam Goldman and Katie Benner

articles.headline: How Los Angeles Times Handled Exposé Becomes the Talk of the Town
articles.snippet: A book by a reporter from the newspaper has ignited debate about the way editors dealt with an explosive article he helped write in 2017.
articles.abstract: A book by a reporter from the newspaper has ignited debate about the way editors dealt with an explosive article he helped write in 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Paul Pringle and Matthew Doig were on the same team. Mr. Pringle, a veteran reporter at The Los Angeles Times, and Mr. Doig, an editor at the newspaper, were working on an article that would ultimately expose the drug abuse of a powerful former dean at the University of Southern California.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Chair Upends Antitrust Standards With Meta Lawsuit
articles.snippet: Lina Khan may set off a shift in how Washington regulates competition by filing cases in tech areas before they mature. She faces an uphill climb.
articles.abstract: Lina Khan may set off a shift in how Washington regulates competition by filing cases in tech areas before they mature. She faces an uphill climb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early in her tenure as chair of the Federal Trade Commission, Lina Khan declared that she would rein in the power of the largest technology companies in a dramatically new way.

articles.headline: Big Tech Is Proving Resilient as the Economy Cools
articles.snippet: Tech companies are slowing their frenetic hiring, but a combination of dominance and diversity is turning out to be — yet again — an overwhelming asset.
articles.abstract: Tech companies are slowing their frenetic hiring, but a combination of dominance and diversity is turning out to be — yet again — an overwhelming asset.
articles.lead_paragraph: No boom can last forever, even for the technology industry’s most affluent companies. Investors punished the biggest tech companies earlier this year, erasing $2 trillion in market value over fears the industry would falter in the face of rising inflation and a slowing economy.

articles.headline: U.S. Offer to Swap Russian Arms Dealer for Griner Highlights Uncomfortable Choices
articles.snippet: The negotiations raise questions about what, if any, standards should apply when the United States agrees to trade prisoners.
articles.abstract: The negotiations raise questions about what, if any, standards should apply when the United States agrees to trade prisoners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One is perhaps the world’s most notorious arms dealer, a man known as the “Merchant of Death” who sold weapons to terrorists, rebels and militants around the world before finally being hunted down and locked up for conspiring to kill Americans.

articles.headline: How Streaming Stars Pay the Price of Online Fame
articles.snippet: Stars on Twitch, the video game streaming platform, invite viewers into their homes virtually. What happens when one shows up in person?
articles.abstract: Stars on Twitch, the video game streaming platform, invite viewers into their homes virtually. What happens when one shows up in person?
articles.lead_paragraph: The unwanted visitor rapped on Kaitlyn Siragusa’s front door and peered through the windows of her home on the outskirts of Houston. When she did not answer, he walked around to the back of her house and jiggled a doorknob there.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Kashmir Hill

articles.headline: Exxon and Chevron Report Record Profits on High Oil and Gas Prices
articles.snippet: The energy industry’s windfall followed a spike in prices, resulting mostly from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the global economic rebound from the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.abstract: The energy industry’s windfall followed a spike in prices, resulting mostly from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and the global economic rebound from the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest energy companies in the United States, said on Friday that profits rose to record levels in the second quarter as they continued to reap the benefits of soaring oil and gas prices.

articles.headline: Pay growth and prices picked up, keeping the Fed on track for rate increases.
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge climbed rapidly in June. Wage and benefit gains are fast, too, separate data showed.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation gauge climbed rapidly in June. Wage and benefit gains are fast, too, separate data showed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wages, prices and consumer spending all continued to climb, the latest government data showed Friday — fresh evidence that the economy remains resilient amid fear of a recession, but also that inflation is likely to remain a vexing problem for the Federal Reserve.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Climate Bill ‘Transformative’ for Auto and Energy Industries
articles.snippet: The Senate’s proposal aims to accelerate electric car sales and promote domestic battery manufacturing at China’s expense.
articles.abstract: The Senate’s proposal aims to accelerate electric car sales and promote domestic battery manufacturing at China’s expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: The $369 billion climate and tax package Democrats in the Senate proposed this week could have far-reaching effects on the kinds of cars that Americans drive, where those cars are made and how the country produces its energy. The legislation also aims to break China’s hold on battery supply chains.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: If the Economy Is Shaky, Why Are Company Profits Still Strong?
articles.snippet: Corporate optimism may seem at odds with the Fed’s grim determination to hold back the economy to get inflation down, but earnings tell a story that other data doesn’t.
articles.abstract: Corporate optimism may seem at odds with the Fed’s grim determination to hold back the economy to get inflation down, but earnings tell a story that other data doesn’t.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers are gloomy, the economy is shrinking, the Federal Reserve wants it to keep slowing and economists now say the whole world could be sliding toward recession.
